estion "What is the largest value of \( f(x) - g(x) \)?", we need to follow these steps:
Identify the intervals over which the graphs of \( f(x) \) and \( g(x) \) are defined and where they intersect or diverge from one another.
Calculate the difference \( f(x) - g(x) \) at key points such as intersections, and at the start and end points of each line segment in the graph.
Compare these differences to determine which is the largest over the entire domain.
Confirm that no other portions of the graphs provide a larger difference, focusing on intervals and intersections.

estion "What is the largest value of \(f(x)-g(x)\)?", we need to follow these steps:
Identify the points where both functions \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\) have coordinates provided or where changes in their behavior occur (e.g., where they intersect or where segments begin or end).
For each segment, calculate \(f(x)-g(x)\) using the coordinates or the functions' descriptions if available.
Evaluate these differences at several crucial points (beginning and end of segments, intersections).
Compare all the computed values to find the maximum difference between \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\).
Ensure understanding of the domain constraints (\(0 \leq x \leq 18\)) while performing the calculations to avoid out-of-domain errors.
